messageBody:
Excellent! Good choice of name, too. It will make it perfectly clear
what mapping is being used--for those who've followed this thread,
anyway. Have you included the alternate letters 'Noon' and 'Up'? I've
been thinking that it would be straightforward to implement the rules
for their use from pp 14-15 in the QM in your news program. It would
be an easy first step towards Senior QS.

There are six remaining capital letters that have no assignment in
QS-SAMPA: B, C, F, L, M, and P. They could be used for ligatures,
half-letters, and alternate letter-forms such as the 'Other' letter
advocated by Jon Zuck. (You'll recall that I removed that one from
QS-SAMPA after a careful re-reading of the QM.)

I think it's entirely up to you to decide what you'd like to include
beyond the basic alphabet and punctuation marks listed in QS-SAMPA. I
started to make a list of ligatures, but the list grew and grew until
it became unwieldy. To assign more than six, you'll have to use
letters that are not 7-bit ASCII, or start using punctuation marks and
special characters (which a user would probably like to type now and
then). My current thinking is that my font will not have any
explicitly assigned ligatures at all. But each font designer should
feel free to include some of them.

The most recent version of my list was limited to the 15 ligatures I
felt were most important (with the six most important assigned to B,
C, F, L, M, and P):
http://staff.washington.edu/freeman/qs/qs_proposal3.pdf

I eagerly await ThothSampa!

Thanks, Paul.

Ted


On Dec 1, 2007 2:09 PM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> >
> >
> > I actually suggested releasing a new version of Thoth that uses the
> > QS-SAMPA mapping. Let's call it Thoth No. 2 for the moment. This would
> > allow people to install and use the new version side-by-side with the
> > old one, leaving any documents that were created with the original
> > Thoth unaffected. It would make sense for new development to continue
> > with Thoth No. 2, while Thoth would remain in its present state.
> >
>
> Okay, the new font is created and will be called ThothSampa. I think if
> we want to go with the Sampa encoding, I will eventually change the name
> of ThothSampa to plain old Thoth, and change what is now Thoth to Thoth
> legacy. I don't want to have conflicting encoding schemes, so I hope to
> phase out the old encoding scheme if we accept the new one.
>
> I just need to know where to put the ligatures. Here are the options.
>
> 1. Only reserve a place for Earth /3r/, because unlike the other
> ligatures, it represents a phoneme not really represented by the other
> combined letters. For the other ligatures, I will build a ligature
> table. The advantage of this method is we use ligatures as they were
> meant and reserve spaces for other half letters in senior QS.
>
> 2. Reserve a place for all ligatures. The advantage of this method is
> that one can choose to use or not use a ligature, and one need only
> press one key to trigger the ligature.
>
> Let me know. As soon as we decide, I can release the font.
>
> Paul
>
>
